{{> searchbar}}

Implants are 1 or 2 soft tubes, about 1½ inches (40 mm) long, placed under the skin on the inside of your arm that release the hormone progestin to prevent pregnancy. Implants last 3 to 5 years, depending on the type. During the first months, they may cause irregular bleeding in the middle of your monthly cycle, or more days of menstruation. Or you may have no bleeding at all. You may also have occasional headaches. These changes will go away as your body becomes used to having more progestin.

  • How to use

    Implants can be put in at any time. They must be inserted and removed by a specially trained health worker.

  • Many women think implants are great because…
    • After it is put in, you are protected without having to do anything.
    • No one can tell you are using birth control but you.
    • It lasts for 3 to 5 years, depending on the type.
    • Your menstruation is lighter.
    • If you want to get pregnant, you can soon after you get the implants removed.
    But some women don’t like implants because:
    • They don’t want to use a hormonal method.
    • They don’t want to have irregular bleeding or spotting.
    • Sometimes they can cause acne, headaches, nausea, tender breasts, or other discomforts.
  • Who shouldn’t use it

    Don't use implants if you: have liver problems (jaundice, cirrhosis, tumors); ever had breast cancer; have blood clots in your lungs or legs. Use a method without hormones instead.
